data.text: I myself also am a mortal man, like to all,
And in my motherâ€™s womb was fashioned to be flesh
And when I was born, I drew in the common air,
I was nursed in swaddling clothes, and that with cares.
For there is no king that had any other beginning of birth.
For all men have one entrance into life, and the like going out.
Wherefore I prayed, and understanding was given me:
I preferred her before scepters and thrones,
Neither compared I unto her any precious stone,
I loved her above health and beauty,
All good things together came to me with her,
And I rejoiced in them all, because wisdom goeth before them:
I learned diligently, and do communicate her liberally:
For she is a treasure unto men that never faileth:
God hath granted me to speak as I would,
For in his hand are both we and our words;
For he hath given me certain knowledge of the things that are,
The beginning, ending, and midst of the times:
The circuits of years, and positions of stars:
The natures of living creatures, and the furies of wild beasts:
And all such things as are either secret or manifest, them I know.
For wisdom, which is the worker of all things, taught me:
kind to man,
For wisdom is more moving than any motion:
For she is the breath of the power of God,
For she is the brightness of the everlasting light,
And being but one, she can do all things:
For God loveth none but him that dwelleth with wisdom.
For she is more beautiful than the sun,
For after this cometh night:
